climbs.name: Kublai Khan
climbs.fa: Wally Barker and Alan Bartlett, December 1996

content.description: Follow a strongly right-slanting crack system for about 30 feet.  A few moves over an overhang (crux) lead to a second slanting crack system.  Follow this to the top.  Some of the moves are rather gymnastic, and the crux is rather committing.
content.location: To the right of Ghenghis Khan, this is an obvious right-slanting crack system.

climbs.name: Genghis Khan
climbs.fa: Jon Regelbrugge, Brian Gengler & Eric Easton, 1992

content.description: The route ascends discontinuous vertical and horizontal cracks on an overhanging north face. It begins on a boulder 10' beneath the first of four bolts. Above the bolt a few moves on loose rock leads to a splintered finger / hand crack that ends close to the second bolt. Face climbing between the second and fourth bolts leads to another crack that ends near a bolted rappel station.
content.protection: 1" - 2.5" cams, medium sized stoppers, and quick draws for four bolts provide adequate protection for this climb.
